q1.text: How to estimate average treatment effect (ATE) without randomization?

q1.2.text: Why does simple matching fail in high dimensions?

p1.text: The average treatment effect (ATE) is the expected difference in outcomes under treatment vs control. Without randomization, we use observational data and adjust for confounding.

p2.text: The propensity score is the probability of treatment assignment conditional on observed covariates. It allows matching units with similar treatment likelihood.

p3.text: In high dimensions, exact matching becomes impossible due to the curse of dimensionality. Even close matches diverge in unobserved ways.
